title: Following the Committor Flow: A Data-Driven Discovery of Transition Pathways
summary:
The discovery of transition pathways to unravel distinct reaction mechanisms
and, in general, rare events that occur in molecular systems is still a
challenge. Recent advances have focused on analyzing the transition path
ensemble using the committor probability, widely regarded as the most
informative one-dimensional reaction coordinate. Consistency between transition
pathways and the committor function is essential for accurate mechanistic
insight. In this work, we propose an iterative framework to infer the committor
and, subsequently, to identify the most relevant transition pathways. Starting
from an initial guess for the transition path, we generate biased sampling from
which we train a neural network to approximate the committor probability. From
this learned committor, we extract dominant transition channels as discretized
strings lying on isocommittor surfaces. These pathways are then used to enhance
sampling and iteratively refine both the committor and the transition paths
until convergence. The resulting committor enables accurate estimation of the
reaction rate constant. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on
benchmark systems, including a two-dimensional model potential, peptide
conformational transitions, and a Diels--Alder reaction.
tldr: This paper introduces an iterative, data-driven framework using neural networks to discover transition pathways in molecular systems, particularly for rare events like peptide conformational changes and chemical reactions, by learning and refining the committor probability.
explanation: The paper addresses the challenge of identifying transition pathways in molecular systems, especially for rare events. The core idea is an iterative framework that combines biased sampling with neural network-based learning of the committor probability. The approach starts with an initial guess of the transition path, generates biased sampling, and trains a neural network to approximate the committor. The learned committor helps extract dominant transition channels, which are then used to refine sampling and iteratively improve both the committor and the transition paths. The method's effectiveness is demonstrated on benchmark systems, including peptide conformational transitions, suggesting its potential for understanding complex molecular processes.
interests_alignment: The paper aligns with my interest in machine learning for biomolecules, particularly peptides. The application of neural networks to understand peptide conformational transitions directly relates to my research interests. Although it doesn't directly address peptide self-assembly, the method might be adaptable to studying assembly pathways.

title: Multiscale geometrical and topological learning in the analysis of soft matter collective dynamics
summary:
Understanding the behavior and evolution of a dynamical many-body system by
analyzing patterns in their experimentally captured images is a promising
method relevant for a variety of living and non-living self-assembled systems.
The arrays of moving liquid crystal skyrmions studied here are a representative
example of hierarchically organized materials that exhibit complex
spatiotemporal dynamics driven by multiscale processes. Joint geometric and
topological data analysis (TDA) offers a powerful framework for investigating
such systems by capturing the underlying structure of the data at multiple
scales. In the TDA approach, we introduce the $\Psi$-function, a robust
numerical topological descriptor related to both the spatiotemporal changes in
the size and shape of individual topological solitons and the emergence of
regions with their different spatial organization. The geometric method based
on the analysis of vector fields generated from images of skyrmion ensembles
offers insights into the nonlinear physical mechanisms of the system's response
to external stimuli and provides a basis for comparison with theoretical
predictions. The methodology presented here is very general and can provide a
characterization of system behavior both at the level of individual
pattern-forming agents and as a whole, allowing one to relate the results of
image data analysis to processes occurring in a physical, chemical, or
biological system in the real world.
tldr: This paper presents a multiscale geometrical and topological data analysis (TDA) approach for analyzing the collective dynamics of soft matter systems, specifically arrays of moving liquid crystal skyrmions, using a novel descriptor called the Ψ-function and vector field analysis. The methodology is proposed as generalizable to physical, chemical, and biological systems based on image analysis.
explanation: The paper introduces a method combining geometrical and topological data analysis (TDA) to study the dynamics of complex, self-assembled systems. It uses arrays of moving liquid crystal skyrmions as a representative example. The key innovations appear to be the \Psi-function, a topological descriptor purportedly superior to existing methods for tracking spatiotemporal changes, and the use of vector field analysis to extract insights into nonlinear physical mechanisms. The approach aims to characterize system behavior from individual agents to the entire collective, claiming broad applicability beyond the specific skyrmion example.
interests_alignment: The paper is tangentially relevant. While not directly about peptide self-assembly, the methods (TDA, geometrical analysis, ML for image analysis) and the focus on self-assembled systems are potentially relevant. I'm interested in machine learning for biomolecules and peptide self-assembly, so a machine learning approach to other self-assembling system can be relevant.
